Questions.QuestionText:
What are the three main elements that shape the content of a paragraph?
Hint: Look for a diagram.
Questions.AnswerText: Figure 6.1 illustrates how purpose, audience, and tone work together to shape content.

Questions.QuestionText:
The chapter identifies four common academic purposes. What are the paragraphs called?
Hint: Skim and look for headings and subheadings.
Questions.AnswerText: The four common academic purposes (summary, analysis, synthesis, and evaluation) are listed after the diagram of the purpose, audience, tone, and content triangle (figure 6.1).

Questions.QuestionText:
The chapter provides some tips on identifying the audience and offers four traits or characteristics we can use to describe or anticipate our imaginary reader. What are the names given to these traits and characteristics?
Hint: Skim for a heading and then a list of traits.
Questions.AnswerText: At the end of the section with the heading Identifying the Audience, the four traits (demographics, education, prior knowledge, expectations) are identified in a box.

Questions.QuestionText:
How many key takeaways does the text suggest you should be able to retain after reading the chapter more thoroughly?
Hint: This is a conclusion to the chapter, so look at the end.
Questions.AnswerText: At the very end of the chapter, the text identifies in a distinctive box six key takeaways from the reading.
